content: # Hot Water Cylinder Fault Finding Guide
This guide provides comprehensive diagnostic procedures for both vented and unvented hot water cylinders, covering common faults, testing methods, and remedial actions.
- Fed from a cold water storage tank in the loft
- Typically copper cylinder with minimal controls
- Open vent pipe running to the cold water tank
- Often found in older properties with conventional heating systems
- Low to medium water pressure at hot taps
- Feed pipe from tank to cylinder
- Connected directly to mains water supply (no tank required)
- Multiple safety devices visible on cylinder
- High pressure water at hot taps
- Temperature and pressure relief valve (T&P valve)
- Two-port motorized valve (if part of heating system)
## PART 2: COMMON ISSUES WITH VENTED CYLINDERS
1. Check for power to immersion heater
- Check consumer unit for tripped breaker
- Use multimeter to check continuity of element (normal reading: 12-30 Ohms)
- Check cylinder thermostat is calling for heat
- Confirm pump is running when hot water is called for
4. Check cold water tank level and feed pipe
- Inspect cold water tank for sufficient water level
- Check for blockages or kinks in feed pipe
4. Float valve issue in cold water tank
- If only affecting one tap, issue is likely local to that outlet
- If affecting all outlets, issue is with the cylinder or feed
- Verify float valve is fully opening
- Look for debris that could be entering system
- Symptoms include gradual reduction in flow over time
- More common in hard water areas
3. Sediment buildup at bottom of cylinder
- Sulfur smell ("rotten eggs") indicates bacterial growth
- Cloudy water may indicate air in system or sediment
- If clears after running water briefly, likely localized issue
- If persistent, may indicate significant cylinder corrosion
1. Identify type and timing of noise
- Hammering occurs when taps are closed quickly
- Ticking often relates to thermal expansion/contraction
- Check for scale buildup on immersion heater
- Test if temperature setting affects noise level
## PART 3: COMMON ISSUES WITH UNVENTED CYLINDERS
- Check expansion vessel pressure with tire gauge (should be 0.1-0.2 bar below PRV setting)
- If water comes out of air valve, diaphragm has failed
- Check discharge pipe for evidence of pressure relief valve operation
### Water Discharge from Tundish or Relief Pipes
- Failed check valve in cold supply
- Temperature and pressure relief valve failure
- Occasional drips during heating may be normal
- Continuous flow indicates a significant problem
- If water is excessively hot, thermostat may have failed
- Follow procedure above for checking expansion vessel
- Verify inlet pressure is not excessive
- Test outlet pressure with gauge (typically 3 bar)
**IMPORTANT: If substantial water is discharging through the temperature and pressure relief valve, this indicates a serious safety issue that requires immediate professional attention.**
### No or Poor Hot Water Flow
1. Strainer/filter blockage in pressure reducing valve
2. Scale buildup in pipes or heat exchanger
- If cold flow is also poor, issue is likely before the cylinder
- If cold flow is good, issue is specific to hot water system
- Use pressure gauge to measure static pressure
- Normal pressure should be consistent with PRV setting (typically 3 bar)
- Higher temperatures increase risk of scalding and scale formation
2. Verify correct operation of thermal cut-out
- This is a safety device that should stop heating if temperature exceeds safe limit
- Usually requires manual reset if tripped
- Use thermometer to measure hot water temperature
- Consistently excessive temperatures indicate control failure
**WARNING: Overheating in an unvented cylinder is a serious safety concern that can lead to scalding injuries or system failure. Professional assistance should be sought immediately.**
1. Switch off power to immersion heater at consumer unit
- Open circuit (infinite resistance) indicates failed element
- With power off, check continuity across thermostat contacts
- Should have continuity when thermostat is calling for heat
- No continuity when temperature is satisfied
- Tire pressure gauge with Schrader valve attachment
4. Remove cap from Schrader valve on expansion vessel
- If water comes out, diaphragm has failed
- If air comes out, check pressure
- Should be 0.1-0.2 bar below PRV setting
7. If pressure is low, recharge using pump to correct pressure
### Testing Temperature and Pressure Relief Valves
1. Locate T&P valve (usually at top of cylinder)
- Valve should re-seat properly when lever is released
- Continuous discharge after testing indicates valve needs replacement
**Note: This test will discharge hot water, take appropriate precautions.**
### Testing Cold Water Tank Float Valves (Vented Systems)
- Check for cracks or water ingress in float
- Verify arm moves freely and is not bent
- If too high, adjust float arm
- Manually lift float to close valve
- Release slowly to check smooth operation
- Listen for hissing which indicates leak past washer
- Look for signs of leaks or corrosion
1. Consider descaling if in hard water area
2. Check/replace immersion heater if efficiency declining
- Look for signs of leaks or corrosion
- Test for pressure creep (indication of check valve failure)
- Service should be documented and certified
- Only G3 qualified engineers can legally service unvented cylinders

**WARNING: Unvented cylinders are pressurized systems that can be dangerous if not properly maintained. Annual servicing by a qualified engineer is not only recommended but is required to maintain safety and warranty coverage.**
| System Pressure (Unvented) | 3 bar (cold) | >4 bar or <1 bar |
| Expansion Vessel Pressure | 2.8 bar | <2 bar or water from valve |
| Immersion Element Resistance | 12-30 Ohms | Infinite (open circuit) |
| PRV Outlet Pressure | 3 bar | Fluctuating or >3.5 bar |
| Expansion Relief | 6 bar | Protects against excessive pressure |
| T&P Relief | 90-95°C or 7 bar | Protects against overheating and pressure |
| P&T Relief | 90-95°C or 10 bar | Used in some older systems |
| Discharge Point | Flow Rate | Likely Cause |
| Tundish | Constant trickle | PRV failure or expansion vessel issue |
| Tundish | Strong flow | Serious fault - thermal cut-out or T&P valve |
| Cold tank overflow | Constant flow | Float valve failure |
| Vent pipe (vented system) | Occasional when heating | Normal expansion |
| Vent pipe (vented system) | Constant/heavy | Blockage in return path or excessive heating |
- Must be installed by G3 qualified engineer
- Must include all specified safety devices
- Annual service by G3 qualified engineer
- Failure to service may invalidate insurance and warranty
- Safety valves must not be capped or blocked
- Discharge pipes must not be obstructed
- Original parts must be used for replacements
- Water above 60°C can cause serious burns within seconds
- Consider thermostatic mixing valves for vulnerable users
- Regularly check water temperature at outlets
- Cylinder temperature should not be set below 55°C
- Regular usage of all outlets helps prevent stagnation
